bibl.title: Letter from Louis A. La Garde to the Surgeon General, September 9, 1902

div1.p: La Garde writes a letter of recommendation for Carroll who is applying for admission into the Medical Corps of the Army. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Louis A. La Garde to the Surgeon General, September 9, 1902
div1.opener:
U. S. Soldiers Home D.C.
Sept 9 '02
The Surgeon General U. S. A.
Washington D.C.
Sir:
div1.p:
Having learned that Acting
Asst. Surgn. James Carroll U. S. A.
is about to present himself as a candidate
for examination before the Medical Ex-
amining Board for the position of Assistant Surgeon
in the Army, it gives me pleasure to
testify to Doctor Carrolls qualifications
as a practitioner of medicine. While he
was still a Hospital Steward in the
army, and a graduate of medicine
as well, Doctor Carroll served under
me at Ft. McHenry M.D. for one year
and a half during which time my duties
with the War Department Board to the
Columbian Exposition required my
repeated and prolonged absence from
the post. Steward Carroll as he
was then known, attended to all the sick
in quarters and hospital at such times,
including these of the enlisted men and
officers families, with entire satisfaction
to them, and to my entire and absolute satis
faction as well. I had frequent cause
to consult with him over difficult cases
in which I found him well informed.

He pursued during this time in a
most creditable way to himself and the
faculty of the John Hopkins University
a thorough course in bacteriology and
pathology when he laid the foundation
for the special work that has since
made him famous. He had entire charge
of the biological and other laboratories
under me in the government exhibits
of the Columbian Exposition in 1893
where he rendered such able service
that he was eventually selected to do duty
with the Army Medical School with which
he has been connected ever since.
I believe Doctor Carroll is over the
age limit as required by the regulations,
but as this has been waved in other cases,
I am sure that no mistake will be made
in according him the permission to appear
before the Board.
div1.closer: Very Respectfully Louis A. La Garde Major and Surgeon U. S. A.
